text: Absolutely, I remember that app well, I really miss those days when so many new ideas were being explored

elements.text: Absolutely, I remember that app well, I really miss those days when so many new ideas were being explored

text: For a while I thought this was the case too, but I don't buy into this narrative any more. There is a ton of innovation happening in smaller "scenes" that just isn't very legible to media outlets and these influencer types and VCs. Imo the most interesting work is often the most obscure. The frontier is not glittzy and has no press-releases, in fact often it might be deliberately staying under the radar. So I think the opinions about innovation from these established personalities should be taken in mind with the maturity of their careers, which often corresponds with how deeply embedded they are in stale systems.

text:
Dedicating today's Midweek Patch Therapy to exploring the quite exciting upcoming Stride game engine integration into vvvv gamma.
This enables 3D live visual programming in the .NET environment with many exciting possibilities.

We're starting at 17:30 CET, come on in
<https://therapy.domj.net/>

Read more about the integration: <https://vvvv.org/blog/vl.stride-earlyaccess-available-now>

text: I don't disagree. (I'd love to hear any examples of innovative work.) Based on your description, it's unclear if the innovative work you're talking about has also been market viable? That was a nice thing about the early 2000s, many of these products were also profitable.

elements.text: I don't disagree. (I'd love to hear any examples of innovative work.) Based on your description, it's unclear if the innovative work you're talking about has also been market viable? That was a nice thing about the early 2000s, many of these products were also profitable.

text: <@UMWF81HTP> So what/where are those small scenes, and how would an outsider find them? I think discoverability matters as well for innovation, because it's a condition for getting feedback from diverse sources, and not just a small bubble of friends.

elements.text: So what/where are those small scenes, and how would an outsider find them? I think discoverability matters as well for innovation, because it's a condition for getting feedback from diverse sources, and not just a small bubble of friends.

text:
Also I can recommend Hammock driven development. It is not strictly about creating programs, but more about how a person can create something big and elegant. This talk really blew my mind, I watched it 2 times in a row making notes :slightly_smiling_face:

Your list is good btw, really like those talks

Thanks <@UC6997THT> (<https://futureofcoding.slack.com/archives/C5T9GPWFL/p1597861763127000?thread_ts=1593726809.181800&cid=C5T9GPWFL|https://futureofcoding.slack.com/archives/C5T9GPWFL/p1597861763127000?thread_ts=1593726809.181800&cid=C5T9GPWFL>)

attachments.title: Felienne/hedy
attachments.text: Hedy is a gradual programming language, which increases in syntactic elements level by level. - Felienne/hedy

elements.text: A blueprint for incrementally teaching programming:

text:
Learning to model in 3D is hard, as in expect to spend 2-3hrs a day for 15 to 30 days to learn Blender or Maya or 3DSMax or Cinema4D or Houdini or ZBrush or AutoCAD and maybe someday someone will figure out a way to make it easier (VR?) but when you look into it there's a reason and purpose for every one of the 6000+ features of blender or maya or 3dsmax and 2 weeks of work might get you some cubes and spheres on the screen but you won't be modeling characters for Uncharted or sofas for Ikea or cars for BMW.

It's nice if they are having fun but the idea that they got frustrated spending 30 minutes in a modeling tool and then spent 2 weeks making their own suggests mostly that in a year or two they'll realize they really should have spent the time to learn a modeling package if their goal was to model something.

It mean it's kind of like saying "I spent 30 minutes trying to learn guitar but it was too hard so I wrote some code to make chiptunes". Yea okay but you still don't know how to play the guitar and no amount of diddling with chiptunes is going to get you closer to being able to play that guitar.

PS: there are programs that make 3D modeling easier but they almost always fall short once you get serious. Like notepad is easier than vi and iMovie is easier than Final Cut Pro and MSPaint is easier than Photoshop

Learning to model in 3D is hard, as in expect to spend 2-3hrs a day for 15 to 30 days to learn Blender or Maya or 3DSMax or Cinema4D or Houdini or ZBrush or AutoCAD and maybe someday someone will figure out a way to make it easier (VR?) but when you look into it there's a reason and purpose for every one of the 6000+ features of blender or maya or 3dsmax and 2 weeks of work might get you some cubes and spheres on the screen but you won't be modeling characters for Uncharted or sofas for Ikea or cars for BMW.

It's nice if they are having fun but the idea that they got frustrated spending 30 minutes in a modeling tool and then spent 2 weeks making their own suggests mostly that in a year or two they'll realize they really should have spent the time to learn a modeling package if their goal was to model something.

It mean it's kind of like saying "I spent 30 minutes trying to learn guitar but it was too hard so I wrote some code to make chiptunes". Yea okay but you still don't know how to play the guitar and no amount of diddling with chiptunes is going to get you closer to being able to play that guitar.

PS: there are programs that make 3D modeling easier but they almost always fall short once you get serious. Like notepad is easier than vi and iMovie is easier than Final Cut Pro and MSPaint is easier than Photoshop
